title: Wonderful
comment: Nice application, waiting for future support of encryption and authorization.

title: Works! But obstructs "Ok Google" Hotword detection
comment: Been using the app sine quite sometime now. Recently is when I noticed that,  "Ok Google" hotword detection on the phone  stopped. After a lot of looking around and several steps, When i deactivated LinConnect as from notifications,   "Ok Google" hotword detection started working. Do have a look at this issues. Waiting for a reply and will be onliged with any assistance from my side

title: Decent, but too early of development.
comment: I will rate it 4 stars when the development becomes more defined.  This is too early to tell, everything works, but its too simplistic.  I ran it on suse, deb, fedora, arch, slax, just off the top of my head and no issues, other than my own forgetfulness enabling ufw access after updates and selinux binding.

title: Great!
comment: This works brilliantly with Elementary OS. Nice to be able to have my Android notifications integrate with my chosen desktop. Thank You!
Works great. You need to enable Notification Access for linconnect in Security settings in Android. Would be 5 star if you can also show notification text as well.

title: Amazing!
comment: I am running Arch Linux and it works great!
Only for linux user:-)

title: Disappointed
comment: This app has a lot of potential. I'm using an HTC One M8 and Linux Mint 17. Server installs fine, app installs fine, but test notification won't go through. Server is detected but the app can't send the test notification. Oh well.

title: trouble in ubuntu 14
comment: After installing LinConnect on Ubuntu 14.10, I can send a test notification successfully it says in app.  However, it does not appear on my Linux desktop's screen. Is there something I have to install first? I notice some information in the terminal window and some error message about Apache server. Please reply.
great app

title: Awesome
comment: What is was looking for. Now Linux is better than windows or Mac.

title: Essential
comment: I honestly don't know if I could live without it. When I'm on my computer, I usually wear headphones, so I'm usually not able to answer calls. However, Linconnect changes all of that, and fits my workflow perfectly.

title: Good app
comment: Is it not supported in android lollipop??

title: Very useful software
comment: Its a very useful software, but there is one little suggestion that I have that I think can improve it. If you can make this application detect whether the user is actively using the device or not, and if they are using it, then there isn't any point to send the notification. Because they are seeing the notification themselves on the device. For example if you can make an option in the configuration page of the application, something like: "Send notifications only when the device is locked." and the application detects that the phone is locked (not in use physically) it should send the notification, otherwise not. That too could be an 'option' of course for those who'd like to opt for it. The reason I am saying this could be useful is because in my Ubuntu setup, I keep a record of all the notifications like android. So all of the notifications that I received when I was away are stacked. Now, when I am away from my computer, I am probably using my phone. So when i come back, at times i have up to 50 or 60 notifications which all of them I have read on the phone.  Do you think this is possible?

title: excellent app
comment: Just works. (especially good with recent-notifications indicator). Server side needs some fixing and might not show notifications with percent values in text.

title: Server not found
comment: Server and client installed. LinConnect enabled both in-app and in accessibility. Server running, same network... no server seen... Custom server ip returns test notification not received error. Help appreciated :)

It doesn't work on my Ubuntu, why? And doesn't show up on my HUD nor can i uninstall it now. I don't want the sit in my comp for nothing. Please let me know how to remove files it has installed in my computer. Thanks

title: Awesome...
comment: Great idea. Good implementation...
Nice

title: Server is seen, but not sending test notification
comment: 14.04, I got it to work before, don't remember how

title: love it
comment: awesome

title: (15 stars!) Best PC notifier for android/ubuntu ever
comment: Modern UI, everything works, and with airdroid 2, very practical. Definitely 15 stars!
Good

title: Nice
comment: It works

title: Great idea!
comment: Wonderful dev and awesome application!
Sure is! Check out my other repository, linconnect-client on GitHub.

title: Ubuntu support
comment: It worked a charm on my Ubuntu 13.10 laptop, but it doesn't work on the new version. Please fix!!!
Does it display an error message by any chance? If so, post a bug report and I'll get it fixed as soon as I can.

title: Fantastic application
comment: I would request few features for server  1. Ability to have multiple accounts for multiple devices protected by password. 2. Can we have some remote control for device from server?   Its fantastic app.. We can also have plugins to make it an open source mightysms clone :)

title: Not Receiving Notifications!
comment: App appears to be promising. I have installed LinConnect on my phone as well as ubuntu desktop. I am receiving test notification on my desktop when i configure the app on phone but I am not getting any further notifications from my phone. I have checked 'Enable All App' options. Kindly help me to solve it. I am using Android 4.0.4 and ubuntu 13.10. Thanks in advance.
Did you enable the notification service? Open LinConnect, tap "Enable notification service", and check the check box next to LinConnect. If you still need help, email me at the address below.

title: Works well
comment: This works quite well and is lightweight on the phone. I've installed the server on Ubuntu 12.04 with no trouble, although some fiddling needs to be done if you want the notifications to properly appear on a Gnome desktop (upper right corner with the rest of them).  ** In answer to yycode: I had to install a Gnome extension to get the notifications to display in the upper right hand corner. I don't think it's anything you can control with the way Gnome is currently set up.
Would you mind telling me the tweaks you had to make so I can set that up by default?

title: Set up and go!
comment: Does exactly what it says on the tin. I can now just turn the sound off of my phone and my computer tells me when anything has happened

title: Working Great! (Until Yesterday)
comment: I've been using LinConnect for a long time now, and then all of the sudden notifications start showing up as seemingly random strings on my desktop. Icon shows fine, but replacing the notification title and description is a set of random letters and numbers. Other than this, I love LinConnect for displaying for accessing notifications from somewhere from the desktop :D http://i.imgur.com/fsz669o.png

Glad you like it! Looks like your server hasn't been updated in awhile. Either restart your computer while connected to the internet to auto-update, run the update.sh script in ~/.LinConnect, or reinstall it from GitHub.

title: good app
comment: it has a lot going for this app. I installed it on Ubuntu 12.04 and Android 4.2.2 It worked fine for a few minutes. Then it gave error please update server message not received.
That likely means that your Internet connection went down. Email me at the address below and I'll help you get it working.

title: Great app
comment: Thank you. Works great with Ubuntu 13.10

title: elementaryOS 0.2
comment: So far so good. No problem at all on my elementaryOS 0.2. Great app.

title: Neat!
comment: Does what it says. It's not as advanced as say, KDE connect, but its useful as is.   The linux android integration world is still pretty new, it'll be interesting to see where this goes.  Running on Arch, btw.

title: LinConnect Alpha works on Mint 16
comment: Works OK in Mint 16 and my Android 4.1.1 mobile but the notifications from my facebook some of them are in Greek and show ASCII characters and symbols .I wish i had more features like combine with airdroid answer my sms or have notification that my battery is low.Good work thought.
The character issue has been fixed in the latest version. Thanks for the patience.

title: I love ubuntu
comment: It's very useful for most ubuntu fans

title: Very useful! Works fine in Ubuntu
comment: Is there a way to make it work using bluetooth connection to the pc?
Not yet, but in the future possibly.

title: Nice app
comment: Very easy to configure

title: Love it...
comment: Since KDE connect, I've wanted something like this. Extremely easy to set up. What I love is that unlike most of these type of apps, it notifies anything. Handy when phone is upstairs and I get a whatsapp. Sometimes I get the message that the port isn't available on the server side which means I can't use it at work. Option to refresh list would be perfect. Great work and I've already wrote a blog about it.
If you find a better/open port, you can change it from the default in the conf.ini file. A refresh button is coming in the next update. Thanks for the feedback!

title: Works great on LinuxMint 16
comment: Looking forward for new features, will be awesome to see ability to answer messages/sms from desktop, if possible.

title: Works great! Funciona bien!
comment: Great work! Keep it up!

title: A great application!
comment: This is a really promising application considering it is only in Alpha. Developer is very responsive and willing to help. Would recommend.  Thanks for supporting open source software and Linux.  Please open source the client!
I'll open source the client in a couple days after I clean up the code a bit.

title: Works very well.Donated!
comment: I would love if it also worked over my data connection.  Also I notice it does not refresh connected systems after I switch from data n/w to wifi. Someway to manually refresh the list would be nice to have.
Thanks! I'll be sure to add that feature in the next update.

title: Nice- but not so simple
comment: The description says "Extremely" simple set-up. For newbies to Linux the instruction "Enter the following command into a console" can not be described as simple particularly if they are using a distro other than Ubuntu or its derivatives.

I think it's safe to say most newbies to Linux use Ubuntu or one of its derivatives, and those that use other distros know how to install a few packages. That being said, I do plan on writing a better install guide and creating install scripts for other distros in the future to further simplify the process.

title: Wonderful Idea
comment: That's the beginning of a great application. I love it and will share it with the community (French & English).   C'est le début d'une superbe application. Je l'adore et je vais la partager avec la communauté (Française & Anglaise).

title: Awesome
comment: Very cool! Works great, and behaves exactly as advertised.

title: Brilliant!
comment: This app is amazing. I'd never even thought about this being something that I needed but now that I have it I can't imagine living without it.
Awesome start.

title: Just what I wanted
comment: I've been looking for something like this for a long time. I put my phone on silent at work so sometimes I will miss a call or text. Great app.

title: Works well
comment: Working great with my Ubuntu powered laptop
